Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation in Economics: Voluntary Separation in Infinitely Repeated Prisoner's Dilemma Game: An Experiment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many economic and social relationships such as employment contracts, membership of voluntary organizations, international alliances, friendships and marriages feature voluntary separation: each participant can unilaterally and voluntarily exit the relationship. On the other hand, voluntary separation often makes it hard to build trust and long-term cooperation. Voluntary separation does not only change how business or social relationships end, it also governs the nature of relationships from the very beginning. Its effect on the level of cooperation will have a profound implication for economic growth, social cohesion and subjective well-being of individuals.

This study experimentally investigates how voluntary separation affects cooperation. Cooperative behavior of subjects will be compared to theoretical predictions. Different social mechanisms will be tested for their effectiveness in inducing cooperation, which could help policy makers or community designers in their choice of regulatory options.

In the experiment, subjects will interact repeatedly in a computer laboratory setting under costly and costless separation. The baseline treatment will not be allowing any separation at all. Theoretical studies on this class of strategic interactions yield predictions based on gradual trust building. In the equilibria they find, long-term cooperation is achieved by mutually defecting in the beginning. This is a highly counter-intuitive way of building trust. There is very little empirical/experimental evidence to support it. This study aims to fill the gap in the literature by answering the following questions: Under what circumstances do people cooperate? Does voluntary separation help or hurt cooperation? How do people achieve cooperation?
To test the theoretical predictions, subjects' cooperative behavior will be compared across treatments. By comparing separation treatments, we can also find out which social mechanisms effectively facilitate cooperation. Finally, potential teaching/learning patterns and persistently heterogeneous behavior among subjects can shed light on formation of norms and socialization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The award yielded three outcomes. First, I collected data from the laboratory experiment using the award. Second, I analyzed the data and wrote a paper that presents the findings. The paper will be submitted to academic journals and included in my dissertation. Main findings of the paper are discussed below. Third, the findings were disseminated via two channels. In 2017, I presented the paper at Economic Science Association world meeting and at NYU economics department experimental seminar. The draft of the paper was also publicly released on SSRN and on my personal website.

 

I find that allowing people to separate freely from their partners does not affect their level of cooperation while they are in the relationship. However, if a separation is costly because meeting a new partner costs money or time,  people are more likely to cooperate to avoid the cost. I also find that the option to separate freely works as a sorting mechanism: Cooperative people sort themselves into a long-term cooperative relationship and therefore exit the pool of singles over time. On the other hand, uncooperative people separate often, frequent the pool of singles and end up with another uncooperative people.

 

The modern economic and social relations have evolved in the direction that allows people to separate more freely with smaller costs. For example, people nowadays make more flexible labor contracts, face less social stigma for a divorce, and find a new job or a new partner more easily with the help of information technology. The above findings suggest that these changes could have two effects: The low cost undermines the general level of cooperation, but improves the equality within each relationship. The findings also suggests why some societies might impose seemingly unnecessary costs to separation, such as social stigma to divorces --  Costly separation facilitate the general level of cooperation within the society.

 

Another finding is that people often succeed in building a cooperative relationship by starting with an uncooperative interaction. In an environment where uncooperative people can exploit cooperative people, many people start a new relationship uncooperatively out of caution. However, a mutual decision to stay together for a few times, despite the lack of cooperation, could signal people’s intention or hopes for a potential long-term benefit within the relationship. This signal motivates one or both people to initiate cooperation. If the other person reciprocate this cooperation, the pair succeeds in building a long-term, cooperative relationship.

 

This somewhat counterintuitive way of achieving cooperation is reminiscent of gift-giving practices found in many cultures. People or communities often exchange gifts that are costly to the giver, but not necessarily useful to the receiver. The rational for sinking in substantial resources in the beginning of a new relationship could be that people want to signal their intention to reap long-term benefits from future long-term cooperation.

 

Finally, the level of cooperation changes over time following a pattern predicted by a mathematical model that assumes that both cooperative behavior and uncooperative behavior are contagious: The initial fraction of cooperative people crucially determines whether cooperation can be sustained in the long-run. This finding leads to a conjecture that social changes that alter the population composition: urbanization, immigration and gentrifications could shake a society out of its current path and result in a different level of cooperation in the long-run.
